ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I've gained experience on applying the data analysis skills I learned in classes to solving real-world problems (in my case, financial economics). My senior thesis encompasses anything from data gathering and cleaning to visualizations and presentations of my results.

I learned how to tackle a data-based research project -- how to pace a long-term project over the course of a semester, handle overwhelming amounts of data, code, graphics and writing, how to get myself out of a rut when I was stuck. A very rewarding experience.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It's very much self-directed and relatively chill if you don't want to spend too much time on it
The course very much depends on the advisor that you choose for advising your senior thesis. I'm lucky to have a very knowledgeable and patient advisor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this is also pretty much a requirement for the S&DS major anyways.

Totally. I think it's a requirement of the major now so you might not have a choice. But put lots of work into your proposal and idea -- if you set yourself up for an engaging and exciting semester, you'll have one. If you don't, you might not. Also, you might not get everything done that you want to, and that's okay, but a good way to prepare for this is to craft a project proposal that will still be interesting even if you don't quite get to the "end" of it (as opposed to an overly-ambitious project with one, perhaps out of reach, deliverable).
